concern:
I'm a rising senior in math looking for research opportunities in machine learning (with a focus on theory). I contacted a professor in June, but I was committed to another project at the time. He briefly mentioned his research interests but advised me to focus on my current work. My previous commitment is over now, and I reached out to him last Saturday, but I haven't received a reply yet. I'm planning to send a follow-up email but I'm really afraid of screwing this up because he's the only professor at my university whose research truly interests me. I would appreciate any suggestions. Here's my email (transcripts attached):

Dear Professor \[name\],

I’m writing this follow-up email to express my strong interest in your research and to inquire whether there are undergraduate research opportunities with you.

I tried to explore the \[research direction\] you mentioned in your previous email. I thought you might be referring to \[paper\] and the subsequent line of work. I’m currently reading the related papers, and I’m very interested in any potential extensions of this idea.

I reproduced GPT-2 from scratch and some results in in-context learning to familiarize myself with the related code. I have a solid background in mathematics and statistics, with PhD-level coursework in real analysis and probability theory, as well as knowledge in learning theory through my previous research work \[linked paper\] in RL theory. I am also always eager to learn new concepts and techniques.

Your work in transformers and LLMs is really intriguing to me, and I would greatly appreciate any potential research opportunities with you.

I will be enrolling in only two required courses in the next academic year, and I will be able to commit fully to research with you. I would truly appreciate any research opportunity you could offer, and I’m very willing to discuss further my qualifications and any related research ideas you might have.

I look forward to hearing back from you. Thank you.

Best regards,

\[Name\]

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! How are you doing today? Is there anything you'd like to talk about or share?
I'm doing alright, but I've been feeling a bit anxious about an important academic opportunity. I'd like to discuss some strategies for managing that anxiety and making decisions.

It sounds like you have an exciting opportunity on the horizon, but it's also causing some anxiety for you. That's completely normal! Let's explore some strategies together to help you manage those anxious feelings and make a decision that feels right for you.

I'm ready to explore those strategies with you, as the anxiety is making it hard for me to feel confident in my next steps. Could we start by talking about ways to build my confidence and reduce overthinking?

Absolutely! One strategy to build confidence and reduce overthinking is to focus on your strengths and past successes. Remind yourself of the skills and knowledge you possess that have helped you succeed in similar situations before. This can help shift your mindset from selfdoubt to selfassuredness. Do you have any specific strengths or successes that come to mind?

Yes, one of my strengths is my solid background in mathematics and statistics, which has helped me succeed in advanced coursework and independent projects. This experience makes me feel more capable when facing academic challenges, even though I'm still working on managing the anxiety around important opportunities.

That's fantastic! It's clear that you have a strong foundation in your field, and that's definitely something to be proud of. It's important to acknowledge and celebrate your accomplishments, even as you work to manage anxiety around new opportunities. One technique you could try is reframing your thoughtsinstead of focusing on what could go wrong, try thinking about what could go right. For example, instead of thinking, I might not be good enough for this opportunity, try thinking, I have a solid background in math and stats, and I'm excited to see how I can apply that knowledge in this new opportunity.

That's a helpful techniqueI'll try reframing my thoughts to focus on potential positives, like drawing on my strong academic background to approach this opportunity with more excitement. Even though anxiety lingers, reminding myself of my past successes is already making me feel a bit more grounded and confident in moving forward.

That's great to hear! It's amazing how a simple shift in perspective can make such a difference in how we feel. Another technique you could try is to break down the opportunity into smaller, manageable steps. Instead of feeling overwhelmed by the entire opportunity, focus on one step at a time. For example, you could start by researching the opportunity, then create a list of pros and cons, and finally, make a decision based on that list. By breaking the opportunity down into smaller steps, it can feel less daunting and more manageable.

That's a useful approachI'll try breaking down this opportunity into smaller steps, like starting with research and listing pros and cons, to make it feel less overwhelming. Even though the anxiety persists, this method could help me build more confidence in my decisions as I move forward.

That's a fantastic idea! Taking a stepbystep approach can make any task feel more achievable. Remember, you've already accomplished so much, and you have the skills and knowledge to tackle this new opportunity. You've got this!

That's encouraging to hear, as it reinforces my ability to handle academic challenges despite the lingering anxiety. I'll keep applying these strategies to feel more in control as I navigate this important opportunity.
